title: Friday, 17th June, 2016

Preamble:

BE

Following the sharp move in the polls to Leave, our UK economists have raised the probability of a vote to Leave to 45%. The result is on a knife-edge, although they expect a late swing in the polls to support an ultimate Remain victory.

BE

In our research (eg - European Economics & Strategy: What Brexit Would Mean for Europe (07 Mar 2016)) we have been forecasting that MSCI Europe would see a 15-20% drop in a base case BREXIT scenario. This compares to a 5-10% rally if the UK votes to remain in the EU.
In this report we discuss the assumptions behind our bull, base and bear case scenarios in the event of Brexit, and apply our forecasts to current spot prices to provide index targets to go with our framework.

BE

European indices are further below their 3M and 6M averages than UK indices, perhaps reflecting concerns over political
contagion into Europe or an expectation that a weaker GBP would limit downside for UK indices (note that our FX
strategy team believe EUR would fall as much, if not more, on Brexit than GBP).
This means that it is plausible that European indices rally harder than UK indices in the event of a vote to Remain.

Enjoy brownies, blondies, and cupcakes with Girl Scouts® Thin Mints® and Caramel & Coconut flavors

BE

oops

11:17 am
BE

Which seems to summarise all our thoughts this morning.

PM

I have some Liberum

PM

UBM has announced that they have completed the sale of PRN to Cision with net cash proceeds of £490m, following the US’s Department Of Justice clearance. The completion now opens the way for UBM to consolidate its shares (8 for 9) and pay out £245m in special dividends. It also opens the way for further acquisitions in the Events space, with UBM’s leverage of 1.1x net debt / EBITDA at YE16E providing nearly £200m of headroom (at 2x leverage). We believe that UBM’s Events First strategy should lead to a re-rating. Reiterate BUY.

11:18 am
PM

Completion of PR Newswire disposal

UBM has this morning announced the completion of the disposal of PR Newswire to Cision. The total net cash proceeds of the transaction are £490m. UBM will return £245m of the proceeds to the shareholders as a special dividend. The special will be payable on the 8th of July to shareholders on the register at 24 June, with the shares trading ex-div on the 27 July. UBM will contribute £10m of proceeds to the UBM pension scheme. There will also be a share consolidation on the 27 June of 8 for 9, which will help offset the dilution of the sale.

PM

Healthy balance sheet to enable further acquisitions

Following the deal we estimate that UBM will de-lever to 1.1x Net debt/EBITDA (assuming no further acquisitions) at YE16E, which should give it scope to make acquisitions – if UBM was to go to 2x leverage, it could make nearly £200m in acquisitions (and it will be helped when it pays off a £250m bond in November which will lead to a reduction in interest charge of roughly £9m). We believe that UBM will continue to target mainly large US events in the mould of the Business Journals Inc. acquisition, we like the US events space which has performed well and could see a further FX benefit from a strengthening dollar. These large shows generally have higher margin and there is potential to geo-clone successful shows around the world, which could boost future organic growth.

UBM PLC (UBM:LSE): Last: 566.00, up 15 (+2.72%), High: 572.00, Low: 560.00, Volume: 660.88k
11:18 am
BE

(@Rushian: what's the news re Just Eat? UberEats London launched yesterday.)

undefined
BE

So even on the most downbeat days, we always have Ocado.

11:19 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 232.81, up 10.11 (+4.54%), High: 232.81, Low: 220.50, Volume: 1.11m
PM

What's happened now?

BE

It's up 4.5% on a SocGen downgrade.

11:20 am
BE

Which must be a bit annoying for the analyst, given he chucked out 80-something pages on the subject of online groceries.

BE

Plus a slideshow. Plus half a dozen breakout notes on the companies.

BE

They've bought a stock image for the cover and everything.

11:21 am
BE

PM

hehehe

BE

Copyright iStock. Though we don't have to pay as it's covered by fair dealing in that context.

11:22 am
BE

So. The upshot is that online's growing, supermarkets have too much floorspace and Amazon's a bit of a concern because it's Amazon.

BE

The wrinkle, though, is that people like their groceries to come from somewhere quite close.

BE

Here are the key conclusions.

11:23 am
BE

1. Online grocery: no miracle development formula. Penetration of online food is very uneven and we see no ‘miracle formula’ for success. Online food development will depend on several factors, including population density, internet penetration and cultural attitudes. In many cases, we think that when penetration is low, this is linked to the reluctance of food retailers to offer a compelling proposition rather than customers’ lack of interest. It is worth noting that things can change very quickly and online food sales can suddenly start to grow dramatically. The most recent convincing example is China which has experienced a real explosion in online food sales over the past two years.

BE

2. Online grocery is local. As with offline, there are tangible differences in online food offerings from one country to another, in terms of dominant formats and consumer behaviour. For food retailers, the real keys to success remain the same as for offline, i.e. strong differentiation and effective execution.

BE

3. The battle should intensify further. All European food retailers have accelerated the roll- out of their multi-channel/online strategies. We have little doubt that online will be a growing factor for differentiation and the battle will intensify further in the coming years.

11:23 am
BE

4. Traditional companies need to reduce selling space. Food retailers need to adapt/optimise the entire business model and not just improve the profitability of their online operations. Online will put more pressure on the poorest-performing locations and underperforming stores.
In the UK, we calculate that the EBIT margin of UK food retailers’ store networks could decrease by c.15bp p.a. on a long-term view, all else being equal. To protect profitability, the sector needs to reduce selling space by 1% per annum in the coming three years and offset 50% of the natural cost inflation through cost cutting.

BE

In France, we expect traditional players to optimise their selling space (arbitrage food/non- food, reallocation of sq. m to shopping malls), but we do not expect any massive move to reduce selling space. Many underperforming stores have already been closed over the past few years.

BE

5. Amazon’s new ambitions could be real threat. Amazon has experienced disappointing development in online food up until now, but we see a growing threat after the wholesale agreement signed with Morrisons. Amazon could put more pressure on the sector, by taking market share, raising customers’ expectations of services level and by reducing the cost of services offered to customers.
In the UK, we think that AmazonFresh could reach £2.1bn of sales in 2020e if it is successful. This would mean a significant slowdown in sales growth for competitors. We estimate that the negative impact on the profitability of competitors’ online grocery business could reach 100-200bp, Tesco and Ocado being the food retailers most at risk. Although we see a risk of cannibalisation for morrisons.com on a long-term view, Morrisons could benefit from the wholesale agreement (£17m of profit in 2020e assuming a 4% margin).

11:24 am
BE

Just to break for a moment ....

BE

Here's what £2.1bn of sales in 2020 -- as in, 13 per cent market share -- looks like.

BE

11:24 am
BE

See? Slideshow as well.

BE

In France, we expect a similar wholesale supply agreement to the one set up in UK (with Casino, Intermarché, Systeme U or Cora as potential partners). If AmazonFresh proves successful, it could lessen the appetite of French customers for click & delivery.

BE

Fantasy M&A section .....

11:25 am
BE

6. Potential M&A: opportunities scarce, but... In food, we generally see limited acquisition opportunities due to a lack of attractive pure players. The key question is whether Ocado could become a potential acquisition candidate for Amazon? We believe this is unlikely in the short term since Amazon will try to develop its online food sales organically in the UK. If it failed, it could become interested by Ocado’s proprietary technologies. Wal-Mart’s priority is to turnaround Asda. In non-food, we think Carrefour and/or Auchan might be interested in France’s La Redoute (generalist catalogue).

BE

And the accompanying slide? Sure.

BE

11:25 am
PM

er, thanks

PM

(SocGen didn't have to break the bank for that image. It's here: http://www.istockp...6630167?st=95ac8d8 You can get 10 images for £25.)

BE

The name that's mysteriously missing from that chart is M&S.

11:25 am
BE

Which has a UK grocery market share in the low single digits, a clear customer overlap with Waitrose, and no online grocery presence.

BE

If anyone's going to buy Ocado -- a business that's still entirely a UK shopping delivery company in spite of its international licencing ambitions -- I'd say M&S makes most sense.

BE

Though clearly, there's a valuation issue to get over first.

11:27 am
BE

As well as the issue that M&S isn't currently in a state to buy anything. They can't even stock their own shelves at the moment.

BE

Back to SocGen though.

BE

7. More cautious on the UK. Online is another reason to remain cautious on the UK, in particular on Tesco (Sell, TP cut from 150p to 130p) and Ocado (initiation of coverage with a Sell rating, 193p TP, implying -11% 12m TSR). They are players we think are most at risk (strong presence in the London area) if AmazonFresh is successful in the UK.
J. Sainsbury (Hold, TP 260p to 250p) is not immune to the Amazon threat but its strong differentiation (high quality products, well-recognised private label) could help protect the business. As regards Morrisons (Sell, unchanged TP 150p), we see a potential risk of cannibalisation of morrisons.com given the wholesale agreement signed with Amazon.

11:27 am

In September 2015, in connection with the preparation of the financial statements for the year ended 31 March 2015, the directors undertook an impairment review of the carrying value of the Kodal Project in Norway in response to the significant fall in the price of iron ore, by performing a value in use calculation. This resulted in an impairment charge in the year to 31 March 2015 of £3,411,664. In the year to 31 March 2016, the Group has recognised a further impairment charge on the Kodal Project of £50,426 representing exploration and evaluation costs in the year prior and the write off of property, plant and equipment associated with the Kodal Project for which an alternative use has not been identified.

Is it all because the costs are too high for decent yet tiny companies to float?

Those companies now go through multiple PE rounds or whatever, while those who can't do that pay up and float to a pool of smallcap institutions on the expectation that they'll be ramped on some godforsaken bulletin board somewhere.

BE

PM

11:40 am
PM

Here's yesterday's "summons" http://www.investe...1606160700083342B/

BE

I read Spangel -- them again -- on this.

BE

Xcite Energy (XEL LN – 10p) – Beginning of a New Way of Doing Things: Today's news that the bond holders have called a trustees meeting is the start of a new phase. It will either be good for investors, as trustees restructure the bonds in return for concessions at the management level, or they perfect their security and force liquidation. Perversely, one route could actually generate a net positive valuation event for the Company's owners, the other, the opposite. Whatever it is, it will be the start of a new phase for the Company, and it's owners.

11:40 am
BE

...... which is an interesting take.

BE

One needs to ask: if the leverage the trustees have over the bondholders is liquidation, why is this positive for shareholders?

PM

Are Spangel actually saying "buy"??

11:43 am
BE

I don't see a recommendation.

BE

If you're a shareholder it's a postitive at the margin, I guess, the bondholders face some opposition. But the two options on the table are that they get zero or they get nearly zero.

BE

I reiterate my earlier point with regards smallcaps.

11:44 am
undefined

Back up the market -- quite far up in fact -- we need to mention National Grid.

PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4BpfXEcEo

11:45 am
National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 952.00, down 9.9 (-1.03%), High: 956.10, Low: 945.00, Volume: 4.42m
BE

.... Which won't be broken up.

PM

Despite what MPs say

11:45 am
PM

MPs are calling for National Grid, the company that runs Britain’s electricity system, to be broken up in a radical move they say could transform the UK’s energy supply.
Members of the cross-party energy select committee have said they believe that National Grid, which is one of Britain’s 20 biggest companies with a market value of £36bn, faces too many conflicts of interest and should be split up.

BE

This is, to summarise, the possible conflict of interest between NG being the Transmission Owner and System Operator.

PM

(urgeview -- no)

11:46 am
BE

America doesn't work that way. So Britain shouldn't either. That's the gist of it.

BE

Here's RBC to talk us through why nothing substantive will happen.

BE

Distributed energy is a growing phenomenon and Distribution Network Operators (DNOs), such as SSE and Iberdola, "remain somewhat blind to their
energy flows and passive in managing them", the ECCC argues. The committee recommends that DNOs must transition to a more active role as
Distribution System Operators so they can manage ever more complicated energy flows.
Separately the committee found that small-scale generators faced "long and uncertain queues to connect to the grid" and that the cost of connections
was high compared to other countries. It has therefore recommended a review of connection costs.

So what? While this news is unwelcome for National Grid it should not be a complete surprise to the market as both Amber Rudd’s previous comments
(originally in November 2015) and the request for a committee investigation were well known. Previously we have stated we did not feel a separate SO is
entirely necessary and that National Grid should be best placed to continue its SO role with appropriate ring-fencing in place. However, if National Grid
loses the SO role it is a clear there will be a small loss to future earnings. For context, the transmission network within NG currently has an RCV of around
£12bn versus the SO RCV at around £100m. From the SO RCV, NG earned around £56m of EBIT in FY16A. The earnings impact of losing the SO role would
be just over 1% of EPS based on these numbers.

11:48 am
BE

And Credit Suisse ...........

BE

 A read of the recent OFGEM document on competitive tendering demonstrates the difficulties in NG being forced to run tenders for its own assets. The “early tenders” would be run by the system operator. The “late tenders” would be run by the transmission owner. We think there would need to be a lot of controls put in place to prevent passing of information and resolving conflicts of interest. Especially with the move to competitive tendering.
 DECC, OFGEM and the National Infrastructure Commission have been discussing options for the system operator since late-2014. And OFGEM has already put in place additional controls. But clearly one conflict—not yet solved—is in ownership of the asset. The report is not conclusive and we would not be surprised to see NG offer to put in place more controls.
 The Electricity system owner is small. It has a c£153m RAB. But there are +/- incentives
(which NG tends to outperform on) and we value the business at c£433m (5x EV/EBITDA).
However, it would make it more difficult for NG to retain capex in its regulated business and we think would reduce the valuation.

undefined

PM

Here's something a bit different

PM

Breakdown of handbag sales in France, by price point

PM

11:51 am
PM

Can you believe that? More than 1 in 10 handbag purchases cost more than 3k euros

BE

Wait wait wait. I can guarantee that handbags costing less than E1k have more than 12% of the market.

BE

I very rarely see a market stall in Shepherds Bush pricing them at more than a fiver.

11:52 am
BE

I assume this is some kind of luxury goods topslicing exercise.

PM

Well, Shepherds Bush hasnt made it into the latest UBS evidence lab

PM

11:53 am
PM

You can have the cover page

PM

Pricing environment subdued; mix moves dependent on brand strength
We remain cautious on the near-term pricing outlook for the industry. Harnessing our
UBS Evidence Lab database of over 75,000 SKUs, we have looked at how price and mix
is changing in the industry year-to-date. Like-for-like pricing is flat to down c.2%
globally with some brands reinforcing the entry level offer. Key will be if we see any
improving volume outlook from such moves. In the current environment we continue
to see the stronger megabrands Gucci and Louis Vuitton as best positioned. We have
seen both brands increase median handbag price points in Europe greater than10% since
December, which we expect to continue to benefit sales growth trends.

PM

Gucci/ Louis Vuitton best positioned in handbags; others reinforcing entry level
Our UBS Evidence Lab pricing database shows that the megabrands Louis Vuitton and
Gucci have increased their median price points in handbags +10% and +14% since
December. At Gucci this has notably been driven by the new product introductions
detailed at its investor day. Elsewhere we have also seen Prada take mix but we believe
this will continue to be offset by volume market share losses. Smaller brands such as
Ferragamo and Tod's have been strengthening the less than €1,000 offer. This may be due to
introductions of smaller bags which should not impact gross margin.

11:53 am
PM

Watches price/mix remains negative; volume reaction to new launches is key
Prices within hard luxury are aligned globally which is in stark contrast to the stretched
differentials in soft luxury. Following significant price/mix shifts over the last few years
there has been a gap at retail left at ~CHF 5,000 price point where there is currently
high demand. This has led to new product introductions such as the Drive at Cartier
and key for the industry will be the volume reaction here. Our UBS Evidence Lab work
shows that Cartier watches have just 12% of SKUs below €7,500 currently.
Brands continue to cut price in China/HK, UK and Korea are outperform

PM

Brands continue to cut price in China/HK, UK and Korea are outperformers
Latest regional price differentials place Mainland China at a c45% (Dec c49%)
premium to Europe with Hong Kong at c24% (Dec c32%). Hong Kong is now cheaper
than Japan which may lead to some support ahead. Korea is now the cheapest market
in Asia post VAT refunds and UK prices are much closer to Europe which is leading to
an outperformance here as shown in the Global Blue data.

PM

There. Handbags done

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 155.05, up 2.4 (+1.57%), High: 156.50, Low: 152.15, Volume: 13.55m

BE

11:59 am
BE

We did not break Dobbies out separately in our sum-of-the-parts valuation but this strikes us a decent price and we welcome the continuing elimination of businesses that have the potential to distract from the central task of turning around the core business. At 1.5-2.0% of market cap, this is not a huge deal but neither is it immaterial.

BE

Tesco results on Thursday, incidentally.

BE

Which I think Morgan Stanley previewed.

12:01 pm
BE

Bottom line: Overall, we expect a decent 1Q trading statement from Tesco in both the UK and Internationally. However, in the UK, the +0.5% YoY increase should be achieved at a time when we expect Tesco's main competitor, Asda, to report a -6% – Asda's worst performance in over 50 years. We expect the change of management at Asda (announced last week) to result in a much greater focus on market share. As for Tesco International, we are not sure that the recovery posted over the past 12-18 months is sustainable.

UK: We model a LFL sales increase of +0.5%. This compares to a (preliminary) MS-gathered consensus of +0.2%. If our assumptions are correct, this would mark the second positive LFL sales increase for Tesco in the UK in close to five years (4Q16: +0.9%). If Tesco reports a +0.5% LFL sales increase for 1Q17, we estimate this will translate to a two-year stack decline of -0.4% vs. -0.2% in 4Q16 (as the comparison basis is getting 10bps easier in 4Q). Kantar data suggest a c.1% decline in LFL sales, but they have tended to underestimate Tesco's LFL sales by 100-150 bps in recent quarters. Based on Tesco's estimated internal deflation numbers of 200 bps+, our LFL sales estimate implies LFL volume growth of c.+3%, more or less in line with 4Q15.

International: We expect another solid quarter from a top-line standpoint, driven mostly by a healthy performance in Tesco's two largest international divisions: in Thailand, Tesco Lotus should have benefited from the (temporary) disruption at competitor Big C (recently acquired by TCC). In Poland, Tesco should have benefited from a return of food inflation (c.+1% YoY in 1Q17).
